docs.title: PandoraSat
docs.text: This Python package contains metadata for Pandora and basic functions describing things such as detector sensitivity and zeropoint estimation.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To install you can use

pip install pandorasat --upgrade

You should update your package often, as we frequently put out new versions with updated Current Best Estimates, and some limited new functionality. Check your version number using

import pandorasat as ps
ps.__version__

docs.title: Pandora Information
docs.text: This repository helps you understand what the Pandora SmallSat will be capabale of.

docs.title: Example Usage
docs.text:
Below is an example usage of some of the functionality in this package. In general, this package will allow you to get metadata from specific subsystems of Pandora.

from pandorasat import VisibleDetector, NIRDetector
visda = VisibleDetector()
visda.pixel_scale
visda.pixel_size

nirda = NIRDetector()
nirda.plot_sensitivity()

See our API documentation for full details on the metadata available in this package.

To update any of the values or functions contained within pandora-sat due to new testing, commissioning, etc., please open a pull request. Update the relevant values or functions on your branch and then the updates will be reviewed prior to being merged into the main branch of pandora-sat.

docs.title: Documentation for Hardware
docs.text: The Hardware class contains basic information about Pandora's optics.

docs.title: API Documentation for pandorasat.Hardware
docs.text:
Holds basic metadata on the optics of Pandora

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default mirror_diameter float

Diameter of the Pandora mirror

required

docs.title: mirror_diameter property
docs.text: Diameter of Pandora's mirror. This should be the effective diameter of the primary, removing the secondary diameter.

docs.title: primary_mirror_effective_diameter property
docs.text: Diameter of Pandora's primary mirror that will reflect light.

docs.title: secondary_mirror_physical_diameter property
docs.text: Diameter of Pandora's secondary mirror that will block light.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
pandora-sat is a respository for information about the Pandora spacecraft, its detectors, and its orbit. It holds information on the spacecraft that is independent of pointing and target. This package is continually updated with the most current information on Pandora.

In [2]: Copied! 
import pandorasat as ps
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import astropy.units as u
plt.style.use(ps.PANDORASTYLE)
import pandorasat as ps import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np import astropy.units as u plt.style.use(ps.PANDORASTYLE)

You can initialize the observatory using

In [3]: Copied! 
p = ps.PandoraSat()
p = ps.PandoraSat()

This object acts as a container of the different observatory components: the visible detector (VISDA), the NIR detector (NIRDA), the optics and hardware of the spacecraft (Hardware), and the orbit of the spacecraft (Orbit). You can access each of these components via the following

In [4]: Copied! 
visda = p.VISDA
nirda = p.NIRDA
hardware = p.Hardware
orbit = p.Orbit
visda = p.VISDA nirda = p.NIRDA hardware = p.Hardware orbit = p.Orbit

Each of these objects contains information on each of their respective components. Many of these are very useful quantities such as the pixel_scale of the detectors or the period of the orbit. For example, we can take a look at some of this info using

In [5]: Copied! 
# This will print the pixel scale of the NIR detector
print(p.NIRDA.pixel_size)

# This will print the number of columns of the visible detector
print(p.VISDA.naxis1)
# and the number of rows of the visible detector
print(p.VISDA.naxis2)

# This will print the mirror diameter of Pandora's mirror
print(p.Hardware.mirror_diameter)

# This will print Pandora's orbital period
print(p.Orbit.period)
# This will print the pixel scale of the NIR detector print(p.NIRDA.pixel_size) # This will print the number of columns of the visible detector print(p.VISDA.naxis1) # and the number of rows of the visible detector print(p.VISDA.naxis2) # This will print the mirror diameter of Pandora's mirror print(p.Hardware.mirror_diameter) # This will print Pandora's orbital period print(p.Orbit.period) 
18.0 um / pix
2048.0 pix
2048.0 pix
0.4264141179651537 m
90.0 min

In addition to standalone values, pandora-sat contains useful functions that do thing such as describe the sensitivity of the detectors, convert between magnitude and flux, or estimate the throughput of a detector. Say we wanted to fetch the sensitivity of the NIR and Visible detectors then plot them for easy viewing. We would do that as follows

In [6]: Copied! 
w = np.arange(0.1, 2, 0.01) * u.micron
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(w, nirda.sensitivity(w), label='NIRDA', c='k', ls='-')
ax.plot(w, visda.sensitivity(w), label='VISDA', c='k', ls='--')
ax.set(xlabel='Wavelength [microns]', ylabel=f"Sensitivity [{nirda.sensitivity(w).unit.to_string('latex')}]")
plt.legend()
w = np.arange(0.1, 2, 0.01) * u.micron fig, ax = plt.subplots() ax.plot(w, nirda.sensitivity(w), label='NIRDA', c='k', ls='-') ax.plot(w, visda.sensitivity(w), label='VISDA', c='k', ls='--') ax.set(xlabel='Wavelength [microns]', ylabel=f"Sensitivity [{nirda.sensitivity(w).unit.to_string('latex')}]") plt.legend() Out[6]: 
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x14d830400>

Likewise, we can plot the throughput of the two detectors across the same wavelength regime like so

In [7]: Copied! 
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(w, nirda.throughput(w), label='NIRDA', c='k', ls='-')
ax.plot(w, visda.throughput(w), label='VISDA', c='k', ls='--')
ax.set(xlabel='Wavelength [microns]', ylabel=f"Throughput [Fractional]")
plt.legend()
fig, ax = plt.subplots() ax.plot(w, nirda.throughput(w), label='NIRDA', c='k', ls='-') ax.plot(w, visda.throughput(w), label='VISDA', c='k', ls='--') ax.set(xlabel='Wavelength [microns]', ylabel=f"Throughput [Fractional]") plt.legend() Out[7]: 
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x14df39490>

You can also convert between flux and magnitude on both of Pandora's detectors.

In [8]: Copied! 
nirda.flux_from_mag(10)
nirda.flux_from_mag(10) Out[8]: $3.1963393 \times 10^{-14} \; \mathrm{\frac{erg}{\mathring{A}\,s\,cm^{2}}}$ In [9]: Copied! 
visda.flux_from_mag(10)
visda.flux_from_mag(10) Out[9]: $3.7767034 \times 10^{-13} \; \mathrm{\frac{erg}{\mathring{A}\,s\,cm^{2}}}$ In [10]: Copied! 
nirda.mag_from_flux(1e-15 * u.erg/(u.AA * u.s * u.cm**2))
nirda.mag_from_flux(1e-15 * u.erg/(u.AA * u.s * u.cm**2)) Out[10]: $13.761632 \; \mathrm{}$ In [11]: Copied! 
visda.mag_from_flux(1e-15 * u.erg/(u.AA * u.s * u.cm**2))
visda.mag_from_flux(1e-15 * u.erg/(u.AA * u.s * u.cm**2)) Out[11]: $16.442782 \; \mathrm{}$

docs.title: Documentation for NIRDetector
docs.text:
The NIRDetector class shows you what to expect from the Near IR side of Pandora. The key information on the detector is given below.

NIRDA Detector Size (2048, 2048) Subarray Size (400, 80) Pixel Scale 1.19 \(\mathrm{\frac{{}^{\prime\prime}}{pix}}\) Pixel Size 18.0 \(\mathrm{\frac{\mu m}{pix}}\) Dark Noise 1.0 \(\mathrm{\frac{e^{-}}{s}}\) Wavelength Midpoint 1.30 \(\mathrm{\mu m}\) Pixel Read Time 1.0e-05 \(\mathrm{\frac{s}{pix}}\) Zeropoint 3.196e-10\(\mathrm{\frac{erg}{A\,s\,cm^{2}}}\) R @ 1.3\(\mu m\) 65

docs.title: API Documentation for pandorasat.NIRDetector
docs.text:
Bases: DetectorMixins

Holds information on the Pandora IR detector

docs.title: bias property
docs.text: NIRDA detector bias

docs.title: bias_uncertainty property
docs.text: Uncertainty in NIRDA detector bias. Every integration has a different bias.

docs.title: bits_per_pixel property
docs.text: Number of bits per pixel

docs.title: dark_rate property
docs.text: Dark signal rate, detector only, no thermal

docs.title: gain property
docs.text: detector gain

docs.title: midpoint property
docs.text: Mid point of the sensitivity function

docs.title: naxis1 property
docs.text: WCS's are COLUMN major, so naxis1 is the number of columns

docs.title: naxis2 property
docs.text: WCS's are COLUMN major, so naxis2 is the number of rows

docs.title: non_linearity property
docs.text: NIRDA non linearity

docs.title: pixel_read_time property
docs.text: Pixel read time

docs.title: pixel_scale property
docs.text: Pixel scale of the detector

docs.title: pixel_size property
docs.text: Size of a pixel

docs.title: read_noise property
docs.text: Read noise

docs.title: saturation_limit property
docs.text: NIRDA saturation limit. Bias contributes to saturation.

docs.title: shape property
docs.text: Shape of the detector in pixels

docs.title: stray_light_rate property
docs.text: Stray light rate

docs.title: subarray_size property
docs.text: Size of standard subarray

docs.title: thermal_background_rate property
docs.text: NIRDA thermal background rate

docs.title: zodiacal_background_rate property
docs.text: Zodiacal light background rate

docs.title: apply_gain(values)
docs.text: Applies a single gain value

docs.title: estimate_zeropoint()
docs.text: Use Vega SED to estimate the zeropoint of the detector

docs.title: flux_from_mag(mag)
docs.text: Convert magnitude to flux based on the zeropoint of the detector

docs.title: frame_time(array_size=None)
docs.text: Time to read out one frame of the subarray

docs.title: get_wcs(ra, dec, theta=u.Quantity(0, unit='degree'))
docs.text: Returns an astropy.wcs.WCS object

docs.title: mag_from_flux(flux)
docs.text: Convert flux to magnitude based on the zeropoint of the detector

docs.title: plot_sensitivity(ax=None)
docs.text: Plot the sensitivity of the detector as a function of wavelength

docs.title: qe(wavelength)
docs.text: Calculate the quantum efficiency of the detector.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: wavelength : npt.NDArray Wavelength in microns as astropy.unit

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: qe : npt.NDArray Array of the quantum efficiency of the detector

docs.title: sensitivity(wavelength)
docs.text: Calulate the sensitivity of the detector.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: wavelength : npt.NDArray Wavelength in microns as astropy.unit

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: sensitivity : npt.NDArray Array of the sensitivity of the detector

docs.title: throughput(wavelength)
docs.text: Optical throughput at the specified wavelength(s)

docs.title: Documentation for VISDA
docs.text:
The VisibleDetector class shows you what to expect from the Visible side of Pandora. The key information on the detector is given below.

VISDA Detector Size (2048, 2048) Pixel Scale 0.78 \(\mathrm{\frac{{}^{\prime\prime}}{pix}}\) Pixel Size 6.5 \(\mathrm{\frac{\mu m}{pix}}\) Read Noise 1.5 \(\mathrm{e^{-}}\) Dark Noise 1.0 \(\mathrm{\frac{e^{-}}{s}}\) Bias 100.0 \(\mathrm{e^{-}}\) Wavelength Midpoint 0.56 \(\mathrm{\mu m}\) Integration Time 0.2 \(\mathrm{s}\) Zeropoint 3.777e-09\(\mathrm{\frac{erg}{A\,s\,cm^{2}}}\)
